title: RL33517
content: Under the Impoundment Control Act of 1974, the President can propose to rescind funding from an appropriations act by sending a special message to Congress. If Congress does not approve the rescission within 45 days, the funding must be made available for executive agencies. President George W. Bush, who had item veto authority as Governor of Texas, has advocated for similar power for the President. President George W. Bush advocated for the Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 2006 to address the issue of too many special interest projects. The bill required expedited rescission, where at least one house of Congress had to vote on the proposals. If one house disapproved, the other house could ignore the request. "Under the Line Item Veto Act of 1996, 'enhanced rescission' allowed spending reductions to be permanently cancelled unless Congress passed a disapproval bill, which could be vetoed by the President requiring a two-thirds majority in both chambers." Under expedited rescission, special presidential messages are permanently cancelled unless Congress enacts a disapproval bill. If the President vetoes the disapproval bill, a two-thirds majority in both chambers is required to override the veto. Expedited rescission bills focus on procedural changes in Congress to ensure immediate approval of the President's rescission request. Fast-track procedures encourage an up-or-down vote on the funding rescission proposal. The expedited rescission approach requires congressional approval to rescind funding, but fast-track procedures encourage a prompt up-or-down vote on the President's proposal. It is seen as transferring less power from Congress to the President compared to other approaches. In the past, the House has passed expedited rescission bills annually, with specific procedures outlined in H.R. 2164 in 1992. The expedited rescission approach, outlined in H.R. 1578 in the 103rd Congress, allowed the President to propose rescissions without limits on the amount that could be rescinded, including the ability to eliminate a program by requesting 100% of its funding. This bill also included provisions for expedited judicial review. H.R. 1578 allowed the President to request rescission of 100% of a program's funding, effectively eliminating it. The bill also included provisions for expedited judicial review. In the second session of the 103rd Congress, H.R. 4600 passed the House in 1994 with a substitute amendment for strengthened expedited rescission. H.R. 4600, passed by the House in 1994, allowed submission of special rescission messages at any time and proposed the repeal of targeted tax benefits within 20 days of enactment. A draft expedited rescission bill, titled the Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 2006, was introduced on March 7, 2006. It aimed to amend the Impoundment Control Act by adding a new "Part C -- Legislative Line Item Veto" to authorize the President to rescind targeted tax benefits. The Administration bill proposed to amend the Impoundment Control Act by adding a new "Part C -- Legislative Line Item Veto," granting the President the authority to propose rescission of discretionary budget authority, direct spending items, or targeted tax benefits in a special message to Congress. The President would have flexibility in submitting and packaging these special messages, with no time constraints and the ability to include multiple proposals in a single message. The LLIVA would give the President flexibility in submitting special messages for rescissions without time constraints. A single message can include multiple rescission proposals from various laws, with the requirement that the amounts rescinded must be used for deficit reduction. Budget Committees must adjust allocations within five days of approval, and spending caps under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit must be adjusted by the Office of Management and Budget. The LLIVA would allow the President to submit rescission requests without time constraints. Committee allocations and spending caps would need to be adjusted accordingly. Rescission requests would be considered under fast-track procedures, with a five-day deadline for committees to report the bill without substantive revision. The committee handling the bill must report it within five days without substantial changes, or it will be automatically discharged. A vote on final passage must occur by the 10th day of the session after the bill's introduction. Debate time is limited to four hours in the House and 10 hours in the Senate, with no amendments allowed. Additional expedited procedural rules are outlined for the approval bill's consideration. The LLIVA would grant the President the authority to withhold budget. The LLIVA allows the President to withhold budget authority proposed for rescission or suspend the execution of direct spending for 180 days, with the option to release the funds before the 180 days expire. These provisions have not been previously seen in expedited rescission. Provisions allowing the President to withhold funds proposed for rescission or suspend the execution of direct spending for 180 days have not been previously seen in expedited rescission bills. Supporters argue it provides a temporary mechanism for Congress to consider a President's request, while others view it as unnecessary due to expedited procedures in LLIVA ensuring a final vote within a month. Critics of the 180-day withholding mechanism argue that it could lead to abuse and unnecessary delays, as expedited procedures in LLIVA already ensure a final vote within a month. They believe a shorter period than 180 days would be sufficient for Congress to act on a special message. Additionally, they point out that the bill does not prevent the President from initiating multiple 180-day withholding periods, potentially allowing for the return of policy deferrals invalidated by previous court rulings. The 180-day provision allows for the return of policy deferrals, subject to a one-house veto, but invalidated by court decisions. Supporters argue it is the maximum deferral period, with the President able to release funds earlier if deemed necessary. The language does not mandate early release even if one chamber rejects the approval bill. The LLIVA states that its provisions are severable for judicial review, meaning unconstitutional parts would be removed while the rest remains.
